quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 3 Quiz 5
quiz.subtitle: 3.5: Molecular Geometry: Linear, Trigonal Planar, Tetrahedral
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Basic molecular shapes and bond angles

questions.question: What is the ideal bond angle for a molecule with a tetrahedral molecular geometry?
questions.explanation: A central atom with four bonding pairs and no lone pairs distributes them toward the corners of a tetrahedron, resulting in angles of 109.5°.

questions.question: Which molecular geometry is associated with a central atom having two bonding domains and zero lone pairs?
questions.explanation: With only two electron groups, the furthest apart they can get is 180°, creating a straight line.

questions.question: A molecule of Boron Trifluoride ($BF_3$) has three bonding pairs and no lone pairs on the central atom. What is its shape?
questions.explanation: Three electron groups with no lone pairs result in a flat, triangular arrangement with 120° bond angles.

questions.question: Methane ($CH_4$) is the classic example of which molecular geometry?
questions.explanation: Carbon forms four single bonds with hydrogen, spreading them out to the corners of a tetrahedron.

questions.question: What is the molecular geometry of the Ammonia ($NH_3$) molecule?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen has three bonding pairs and one lone pair. While the electron geometry is tetrahedral, the visible molecular shape is a pyramid.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the shape of a Water ($H_2O$) molecule?
questions.explanation: Oxygen has two bonding pairs and two lone pairs. The lone pairs push the hydrogen atoms closer together, resulting in a 'bent' or V-shape.

questions.question: In a trigonal planar molecule like $CH_2O$, what is the approximate bond angle?
questions.explanation: Trigonal planar geometries divide the 360° of a plane into three equal parts of 120° each.

questions.question: How many lone pairs are present on the central atom of a molecule with a 'Bent' shape and a bond angle of approximately 104.5°?
questions.explanation: A bond angle significantly smaller than 109.5° (like in water) indicates the presence of two lone pairs compressing the angle.

questions.question: Which molecule has a linear geometry despite having more than two atoms?
questions.explanation: Carbon dioxide has two double bonds and no lone pairs on the carbon, keeping the oxygen atoms 180° apart.

questions.question: If a molecule has three bonding pairs and one lone pair, its electron-group geometry is __________, but its molecular geometry is __________.
questions.explanation: Four total domains make the electron-group geometry tetrahedral, but we only 'see' the atoms in the pyramidal shape.

scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Remember that lone pairs change the name of the shape.
